Strings: HelloWorld
Examples
Hello world! Thanks for trying out our dialog system!
What feature would you like to see an example of?
prompt
Adding a \[prompt\] tag adds a prompt[7] after[8] every[9] word.
page

Even though this is a single dialog line, when it hits a \[page\] tag...
[11]...it'll scroll the current line to a new page to read the rest!
goto
The name of this section is "Examples". \[goto Examples\] will return you to the beginning of the section. Let's go!
speed
This text will be read at regular speed.
[15]This will be read at half speed because of the tag \[speed=0.5\].
[17]And this will be read at double speed due to a tag of \[speed=2\]!
pause
This text inserts a pause here[19] then continues on!
auto
If you add an "auto" tag to the end of a line, it will automatically proceed after a pause.
This line ends with \[auto=2\].[22]
You can also set an "auto" tag on its own line. This will make all lines auto-proceed until you turn it off.
We just turned it on and didn't set a pause time (\[auto\]) so it'll auto proceed based on the length of the line.
This will also auto-proceed.
\[/auto\] closes the tag, so you'll need to proceed manually from here!
members

You can define methods and properties to be used in your scripts! To do so, make an additional partial class to go with your Dialog class that is named *.DialogBridge.cs. We made one and added a "Flash()" method! Let's try it.
Flash
Flash![31]
Go to Dialog.DialogBridge.cs to take a look!
await
Shake

In Dialog.DialogBridge we created a custom method, Shake(), that shakes the dialog box. Internally, it's handled asynchronously (Take a look!). You can wait for it to finish before continuing with the script by writing \[await Shake()\][34], or if you don't want to wait, simply call the method name.
\[Shake()\][36]. Notice that it's still writing during the effect. Cool, right?
end
\[end\] ends the script. Goodbye!
